Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 55199-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
November 2021 
 
 
Mongolia: Supporting Inclusive and Sustainable 
Development 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 8 November 2021) 
 
 
Currency unit  –  togrog (MNT) 
MNT1.00  =  $0.00035105 
$1.00  =  MNT2,848.56 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  GAP  –  Government Action Plan 
MOF  –  Ministry of Finance 
  OP  –  operational priority 
  PIU  –  project implementation unit 
  SDG  –  Sustainable Development Goal  
  TA   –  technical assistance  
  UNDP  –  United Nations Development Programme 
       
 
 
NOTE 
 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars.

ThisdocumentmustonlybegeneratedineOps. 04082021090301684302 Generated Date: 25-Oct-2021 7:02:08 AM

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of Mongolia requested knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) 
for advisory support from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) on inclusive and sustainable 
development. The TA is included in the country operations business plan for Mongolia, 20211. 
The TA will provide innovative, flexible, and timely knowledge products, advisory services, and 
capacity development support to the government to enable it to respond effectively to policy and 
capacity development needs associated with the recovery from coronavirus disease (COVID-19) 
and the country’s emerging development challenges.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  COVID-19 has caused a deep economic contraction, slowed progress on macroeconomic 
reform, and exacerbated underlying inequalities in Mongolia. The pandemic caused a contraction 
in overall gross domestic product (GDP) of 5.3% in 2020. This increased the debt–GDP ratio by 
14.1 percentage points and resulted in a stagnation of credit while elevating long-standing risks 
in the finance sector linked to nonperforming loans and weak capital buffers. The COVID-19-
induced contraction has led to job losses in all major sectors and increased unemployment and 
underemployment.3 In addition to the 28.4% of people who live in poverty,3 a further 27.3% of 
Mongolians were living just above the poverty line in 2018.4 Groups that suffered from higher 
poverty before the COVID-19 pandemic, such as women, youth, people with disabilities, younger 
adults (aged 30–39), and rural populations, have been worst hit by COVID-19 with higher job 
losses and a more significant loss of services such as education.5 
 
3.  Historically, frequent shifts at the political level have been accompanied by widespread 
changes in the civil service, presenting a challenge for policy continuity. Reforms are underway 
to address this issue systematically through constitutional amendments, a new Civil Service Law, 
and a civil service reform program supported by the Government of Canada and the United 
Nations Development Programme (UNDP). ADB is also supporting reform of the government’s 
development policy regulations to strengthen continuity at the project level. Another source of 
volatility for Mongolia is economic linked to the country’s dependence on mining, which leaves it 
vulnerable to fluctuations in commodity markets.  
 
4.  In  addition  to  reducing  this  historical  volatility,  Mongolia  has  outlined  an  ambitious 
Government  Action  Plan  (GAP),  2020-2024 6  to  deliver  more  inclusive  and  sustainable 
development. Mongolia also aims to make major policy transitions in many sectors to deliver its 
Vision 2050,7 which strives to expand the middle class underpinned by a modern, inclusive, and 
green economy. Successfully fulfilling this ambition will require shifts in approach in areas such 
as macroeconomics, gender equality, energy, agriculture, finance, infrastructure, tourism, green 
development, and technology. As a small, open economy in an economically dynamic region, 
Mongolia must innovate and adapt quickly to capitalize on its potential. Achieving these policy 
 
1  ADB. 2020. Country Operations Business Plan: Mongolia, 2021. Manila.  
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 26 July 2021. 
3  National Statistics Office of Mongolia. 2021. Statistical Information Services. http://www.1212.mn. Ulaanbaatar; ADB. 
2021. Mongolia Quarterly Economic Insight. Issue #6, and ADB estimates. 
3  The national poverty line is MNT166,580 per capita per month. 
4  Just above the poverty line refers to living within 150% of the national poverty line, or on less than MNT249,870 per 
capita per month. 
5  ADB. 2021. Sustainable Recovery Options for Mongolia’s Micro, Small, and Medium-Sized Enterprises. Manila; and 
UNDP. 2021. COVID-19 Impact on Women and Girls in Mongolia. New York. 
6  Government of Mongolia. 2019. Government Action Plan, 2020–2024. Ulaanbaatar. 
7  Government of Mongolia, State Great Khural. 2020. Mongolia’s Vision-2050. Ulaanbaatar.

2 
 
shifts and adapting quickly will require policy advice and capacity building across a range of areas 
to help deliver more inclusive and sustainable development.  
 
5.  In 2016, ADB approved TA to Mongolia for Macroeconomic Advisory Support to help the 
government respond to the macroeconomic challenges.8 This allowed the government and ADB 
to identify and address emerging, urgent, and/or innovative challenges. Activities facilitated 
important progress in key areas such as removing Mongolia from the Financial Action Task 
Force’s  Anti-Money  Laundering/Combating  the  Financing  of  Terrorism  grey  list,  deepening 
expertise in economic modeling with the Bank of Mongolia (the central bank) and introducing 
innovations including Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) budgeting in partnership with the 
United Nations. The TA for Supporting Inclusive and Sustainable Development is designed to 
provide continued support to the government to address and respond to emerging challenges 
linked to Mongolia’s vulnerability to economic shocks and disasters triggered by natural hazards, 
while progressing to achieve the SDGs and the national development agenda. This vulnerability 
has been accentuated by the COVID-19 crisis. 
 
6.  The TA will help Mongolia respond to emerging development challenges arising from the 
fluid environment described in paras. 2–5. The TA will help the government consolidate the 
improvements in their management of economic volatility observed in recent years. It will mobilize 
knowledge solutions, advisory services, and capacity development to support the resolution of 
development challenges and/or deepen government capacity in core areas. TA implementation 
will be done in close coordination with ADB loans, grants, and TAs with activities in Mongolia. 
ADB will also coordinate closely with other development partners and improving development 
partner coordination is one of the planned activities under the TA. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: inclusive and sustainable implementation of 
the GAP, 2020–2024 achieved. The TA will have the following outcome: policies and measures 
to implement the GAP, 2020–2024 and the SDGs improved.10 This outcome will be achieved 
through the delivery of two outputs: policy advice on inclusive and sustainable development 
provided, and knowledge and skills in public sector management of government staff enhanced. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1: Policy advice on inclusive and sustainable development provided. The TA 
will provide government agencies with advisory services in areas that will contribute to more 
inclusive and sustainable development in Mongolia. All activities will be closely aligned with the 
GAP, 2020–2024 and ADB’s country partnership strategy (CPS) for Mongolia, 2021–2024.9 
Activities  will  include  preparing  knowledge  products  and  providing  policy  advice  through 
organizing conferences, seminars, and workshops on international good practices. The TA will 
support the government to formulate improved policies and plans to deliver on the GAP, 2020-
2024 and to deliver the SDGs. The activities will support improved public financial management 
including enhancing gender-based budgeting in the health sector, improving the use of tax policy 
as a social protection measure and strengthening core public financial management functions 
 
8  ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance to Mongolia for Macroeconomic Advisory Support. Manila.  
10 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
9 ADB. 2021. Mongolia, 2021–2024: Laying Resilient Foundations for Inclusive and Sustainable Growth. Manila.

3 
 
including  revenue  projections  and  options  appraisal.  The  activities  will  also  improve  the 
investment climate by addressing emerging challenges faced by Mongolia in attracting private 
sector investment including finance sector reform, public–private partnerships, and marketing 
Mongolia as an investment destination. The activities will support continuous identification and 
application of good practice in responding to the evolving COVID-19 situation, including planning 
in the health sector, but also in other affected sectors such as education, agriculture, trade, 
services, and business (particularly micro-, small-, and medium-sized enterprises) more generally. 
Some activities will focus on the use and application of new technologies such as carbon 
abatement technologies to combat climate change or information technology to broaden internet 
access. Activities will also support the review and assessment of high potential opportunities to 
support inclusive and sustainable development in Mongolia, for example exploring the potential 
of the rare earth materials sector in Mongolia or providing advisory support to the authorities in 
other export potential sectors. 
 
9.  Output 2: Knowledge and skills in public sector management of government staff 
enhanced. This output will strengthen the development and management capacity of government 
agencies  through  organizational  diagnostics,  capacity  assessments,  training  programs, 
workshops,  conferences,  and  knowledge  management  interventions.  As  with  output  1,  all 
activities will be closely aligned with the GAP, 2020–2024 and ADB’s CPS for Mongolia, 2021–
2024.  The  activities  will  include  training  and  hands-on  support  for  government  officials  to 
strengthen policy formulation, policy and project preparation, implementation and evaluation, and 
development partner coordination. The activities will deepen the capacity of government staff to 
appraise legislation, policies, and projects, including their macroeconomic and socio-economic 
impacts. The activities will also support enhanced capacity on data collection, management, and 
use, including in innovative areas such as big data and artificial intelligence and their application 
to government service functions such as civil registration, audit, traffic and border management, 
and other areas.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
10.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,400,000, of which $1,250,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 7). The key expenditure items are 
listed in Appendix 2. 
 
11.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation, logistics and administrative support, and other in-kind contributions. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  ADB will administer the TA through the Mongolia Resident Mission. The TA will be 
implemented from December 2021 to 15 January 2025. TA support for workshops may include 
costs  related  to  the  venue,  equipment  rental,  translation,  printing  and  copying,  food  and 
nonalcoholic beverages, transportation, lodging, logistics and administrative support, and other 
agreed expenditures with prior written approval from ADB. Disbursements under the TA will be in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2020, as amended time 
to time). The TA may also fund surveys, field investigations, and the purchase of required 
resource  materials,  based  on  cost  estimates  agreed  by  ADB.  In  line  with  standard  ADB 
procedures, the TA will not support implementing agencies’ management fees, overhead, or 
related costs such as staff salaries and allowances, or the use of implementing agencies’ 
resources (such as office accommodation), which will be provided as part of the counterpart 
contribution.  All  procurement  under  the  TA  will  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  ADB

4 
 
Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  its  associated  project 
administration instructions and/or staff instructions. 
 
13.  The  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF)  will  be  the  executing  agency  with  responsibility  for 
oversight and coordination of the activities, to ensure strong coordination with other government 
agencies. Other benefitting agencies are expected to include the Bank of Mongolia, the National 
Development Agency, the National Statistics Office, the Ministry of Health, the Ministry of Labor 
and  Social  Protection  and  others.  Support  for  these  agencies  will  be  coordinated  and 
implemented through MOF. ADB will assist the executing agency in overall TA operations and 
will conduct TA review missions to help monitor progress. ADB will be responsible for the 
recruitment and contracting of all consultants in coordination with the executing agency. The TA 
will establish a project implementation unit (PIU) consisting of a part-time TA coordinator and a 
part-time financial and administrative assistant for day-to-day administration. The PIU will be 
responsible for producing the TA outputs and products in a timely and effective manner, and for 
organizing and carrying out all TA activities. The PIU will report to the ADB project officer.  
 
14.  To facilitate TA implementation, the PIU will establish a separate advance payment facility 
with the MOF in a commercial bank in United States dollars in coordination with the MOF following 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2020, as amended from time to time). This 
will be used to support cash expenditures for workshops, training programs, conferences, survey 
costs, publishing of reports, and other miscellaneous administration and support costs with prior 
agreement from ADB. The TA will not support expenditures that are not reflected in ADB’s 
disbursement  guidelines.11  The  executing  agency  is  assessed  as  having  the  financial 
management capacity and internal control to maintain records.12 ADB will also make certain direct 
payments to service providers (e.g., for equipment and workshop venues). 
 
15.  Implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

5 
 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Disbursement  ADB and the Ministry of Finance will establish an advance payment 
facility to support agreed cash expenditures for workshops, training

ADB = Asian Development Bank, CQS = consultants' qualification selection, TA = technical assistance. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
16.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.13 The TA will engage about 30 person-months of international consulting 
services; 250 person-months of national consulting services; 20 resource persons for workshops, 
seminars, and policy briefs and notes. ADB will engage UNDP through single source selection to 
support  delivery  of  outputs  1  and  2,  in  particular  to  undertake  activities  to  support  the 
implementation  of  the  SDGs.  UNDP  can  leverage  its  presence  in  Mongolia  to  ensure 
implementation  efficiency,  well-coordinated  activities,  and  output  sustainability.  UNDP’s 
engagement is in line with the agreed areas of collaboration and forms of cooperation set out in 
the  memorandum  of  understanding  between  ADB  and  UNDP  dated  13  April  2019.  The 
consultants  will  be  recruited  initially  for  12  person-months  with  a  view  to  extending  their 
engagement if both parties are satisfied. The TA coordinator and financial and administrative 
assistant will be intermittent positions of 24 person-months each to oversee TA implementation 
and ensure high-quality communication of results, strong coordination between the activities, and 
support across all TA outputs.  
 
17.  Financial management. ADB has conducted a financial management assessment of the 
MOF linked to the establishment of the advance payment facility. The assessment confirms the 
MOF’s capacity to manage the funds and has identified no major issues. 
 
18.  Financial management action plan. The financial management assessment proposes 
an action plan that includes (i) hiring qualified financial and administrative assistants, (ii) providing 
training on TA disbursement processes and requirements, (iii) providing financial guidance to the 
executing and implementing agency, and (iv) conducting regular reviews and monitoring of the 
financial management risks. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,250,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Mongolia for Supporting Inclusive and Sustainable Development, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board. 
 
13 Financial Management Assessment (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

6.1.1) 
Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Policy advice on inclusive and sustainable development provided 
1.1 Initiate recruitment of consultants to deliver activities in Q1 2022. The sequencing of recruitment will 
be fully mapped out in the inception report.  
1.2 Provide advisory services to the Government of Mongolia based on contracts agreed with consultants. 
The first knowledge product should be prepared by Q3 2022. 
1.3 Organize conferences, seminars, and workshops based on international good practices to 
disseminate knowledge products. The first such event should take place in Q2 2022.  
 
2.  Knowledge and skills in public sector management of government staff enhanced 
2.1 Initiate recruitment of consultants to deliver training in Q1 2022. The sequencing of recruitment will be 
fully mapped out in the inception report.  
2.2 Prepare training materials and implement training as per contracts agreed with consultants. The first 
training course should take place by Q4 2022. 
TA Management Activities 
Recruit TA coordinator and TA finance and administrative assistant by Q4 2021 
Conduct project inception mission by Q1 2022 
Establish advance payment facility by Q1 2022. 
Finalize agreement with UNDP by Q1 2022. 
Conduct TA Review Missions in Q3 2022, Q1 2023, Q3 2023, Q1 2024 and Q3 2024. 
Conduct mid-term review mission and prepare associated report in Q1 2023. 
Conduct final review mission and prepare associated report in Q3 2024. 
Inputs 
ADB: $1,250,000 (Technical Assistance Special Fund 7) 
Note:  The  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office 
accommodation, office supplies, and other in-kind contributions. 
A = assumption, ADB = Asian Development Bank, MOF = Ministry of Finance, NA = not applicable, OP = operational 
priority, Q = quarter, R = risk, TA = technical assistance, UNDP = United National Development Programme.

in Contribution to Strategy 2030 Operational Priorities (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3 of 
the TA report). 
Source: Asian Development Bank.

Bank (ADB) are presented in the table. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff,

with prior written approval from ADB.

administrative arrangement.
